text: So anyway, I imagine there will be plenty of issues on which I disagree with @PeteButtigieg, but if he's capable of 1) sounding even in passing like Ayn Rand and 2) throwing the established gay organizations into disarray, he's got my attention.
author: walterolson

text: But there is another and important sense in which @PeteButtigieg's observation about the danger of business control of government not only is correct but could have been (and was) said by Ayn Rand.
author: walterolson

text: First, and this is the bad part, he seems to tie in that critique about business and government with views about remedies that I don't agree with (campaign finance restrictions and so forth).
author: walterolson

text: Recently, asked about capitalism's biggest problem, @PeteButtigieg said it was the danger of "business's basically taking over our government." Two things about that:

author: walterolson

text: In short, don't accept the premise that between celebrity / legacy / insider connections on the one hand, and racial preferences on the other, people are just winning with one hand what they give up with the other. Most applicants are losing twice.
author: walterolson

text: If you're an applicant who doesn't fit in *either* the celebrities-and-cheaters pool or the racial-preference pool, things definitely don't somehow cancel out. You're competing with other families like yours for an artificially small number of remaining admission seats.
author: walterolson

text: A recent Princeton study found being in a favored racial or ethnic group gave a boost in admissions equivalent to 180-230 SAT points, while being an Asian-American, a disfavored category, was like having to shoulder a handicap of 50 points.
author: walterolson

text: Many of those arguing that the admissions scandal somehow vindicates racial preferences seem unaware that Singer repeatedly falsified students' ethnicity to get them into affirmative action categories. https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/13/us/admissions-cheating-scandal-consultants.html …
author: walterolson

text: Sometimes I've seen it as a one-off challenge: say one nice thing about a figure on the other team! Often you do see people willing to give it a try, but multiple rounds are harder to pull off, let alone a community built on the practice.
